Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Geometric Singularities in Engineering Design and Manufacturing: A Generic Spacetime Approach

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Early Faculty Career Development (CAREER) award is to develop a generic theoretical framework and computational algorithms for predicting, quantifying, and correcting potential malfunctions induced by geometric singularities, such as undesired loss of contact or changes in the prescribed motion of moving bodies in the presence of uncertainty. The research takes a new approach to the characterization of geometric singularities in the envelopes of families of both rigid and non-rigid moving shapes by reframing the problem in terms of the so-called "fold points" and "fold regions" in the neighborhood of these singularities. Based on this duality, the problem of detecting geometric singularities is recast into Point Membership Classification tests in the original d-dimensional Euclidean space, eliminating the need for envelope computations. In turn, this will result in improved detection and corrective capabilities of such potential failures.

If successful, the results of this research will advance the state of the art in computer aided manufacturing, path planning, and geometric modeling by providing algorithms which will, for example, significantly improve on-line testing of tool paths and CNC codes for arbitrarily complex shapes and motions that will reduce under- or over-cutting in machining, improved swept volume calculations and improved collision detection. New curriculum will be developed and integrated into the mechanical engineering program. Outreach to an all women's college to encourage and actively recruit female students into mechanical engineering and collaboration with a successful existing K-12 outreach program will be performed as part of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Developing a novel and generic theoretical framework and computational algorithms for predicting, quantifying, and correcting malfunction due to loss of contact in a system of contacting pairs of arbitrary complexity is one of the fundamental and long standing open problems in the design and manufacturing of conjugate (contacting) pairs.

The research performed during this project established a novel mathematical characterization of the changes in contact between objects moving relative to each other in terms of the so-called “fold points” and “fold regions” that occur in the neighborhood of geometric singularities. Because our approach does not rely on the traditional envelope computations, it completely avoids the main bottleneck that characterizes all current approaches.

Consequently, we solved a longstanding open problem of classifying points against the set swept by a moving, possibly deformable solid in general affine motion. These results allow the computation of any geometric property of the swept set and significantly extend the current state of the art. The immediate impact of these findings is the ability to detect and quantify singularities for objects moving in contact. Importantly, this research provides the first generic algorithms for predicting and quantifying loss of contact in a conjugate pair, which provide the theoretical and computational foundations for applications as diverse as 3-dimensional solid sweeping in geometric modeling and virtual manufacturing, engineering design, tool path planning, as well as cam and gear design.

We have also proposed a powerful framework for computing distance functions and skeletal representations of shapes, which opens several new research directions. Importantly, our work can potentially have transformative effect in applications such as motion and assembly planning, shape similarity, dimensional reduction in boundary value problems, protein docking and drug design, as well as geometric reasoning, editing and manipulation of 3D shapes. More generally, our work can lead to new and powerful descriptors of shapes in a variety of other applications in which geometric interactions play a central role.

This award funded multiple PhD students and our research produced a significant number of journal and conference publications. Furthermore, the research results were widely disseminated through multiple conferences, invited academic seminars and industrial presentations, as well as through the PIs research website.

The PI repeatedly participated in the NSF funded Joule Fellows Program at UConn, which provides teachers of science, mathematics, and/or technology subjects with a valuable hands-on exposure to ongoing research topics. The outreach activities were augmented through targeted outreach to K-12 students as well as contributions to annual UConn Science Bowls and School of Engineering open houses.
